AN ZOOR15503014471
DT Article
TI Trachyphloeoides weevils rediscovered in China: phylogeny,
   phylogeography, and a second species (Coleoptera, Curculionidae,
   Entiminae, Blosyrini).
AU Grebennikov, Vasily V. (vasily.grebennikov@inspection.gc.ca) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 209-218
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Broad-nosed weevils attributed to the obscure genus Trachyphloeoides
   Formanek, 1907 were detected in the forest-floor litter in three
   mountainous localities in Yunnan, China. This is the first record of the
   monotypic genus since two type specimens of the type species T. sordidus
   (Faust, 1890) were found in Gansu, China, in 1885. The genus is
   illustrated for the first time based on both historical and new
   specimens of T sordidus from Cang Shan and Jizu Shan. A second species,
   T. io n. sp., is described from Haba Shan. The geographic distribution
   of Trachyphloeoides along the south-eastern rim of the Tibetan Plateau
   is mapped. Phylogenetic and phylogeographic analyses of the newly
   discovered populations were performed using the DNA barcode fragment of
   the mitochondria cytochrome oxidase subunit I. Results corroborate the
   hypothesis that monophyletic Trachyphloeoides is the sister group of the
   Dactylotus Glade of Asian Blosyrini; the tribe, however, is
   non-monophyletic with respect to its African members. Temporal analysis
   suggests that mtDNA of both Trachyphloeoides diverged 11.4 (6.3-19.0)
   Mya, while that of both populations of T. sordidus diverged 4.96
   (3.1-6.8) Mya.
C1 Grebennikov, Vasily V.; Canadian Food Inspect Agcy, KW Neatby Bldg,960
   Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0C6, Canada, Canada.
EM vasily.grebennikov@inspection.gc.ca
SC Genetics &Heredity; Zoology; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Taxonomy; Key; Genetics; Evolution;
   Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Trachyphloeoides [Molecular genetics / mtDNA COI barcoding /
   systematics] [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Zoogeography /  / ] [China
   /  / distribution] [Yunnan /  / New record]. 
   Trachyphloeoides io [Yunnan /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Curculionoidea,
   Curculionidae
OR Trachyphloeoides - Formanek 1907 (Curculionidae): [Key to species, P.
   212; New record]. 
   Trachyphloeoides io (Curculionidae): [Sp nov, Yunnan, P. 213]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15503014471
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15503014472
DT Article
TI Re-defined Aparopionella from Afrotropical forest floors comprises 20
   poorly known nominal species (Coleoptera, Curculionidae, Molytinae).
AU Grebennikov, Vastly V. (vasily.grebennikov@inspection.gc.ca) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 219-231
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The presumed monophyletic molytine genus Aparopionella Hustache, 1939 is
   re-defined to embrace 20 Afrotropical nominal species distributed
   between Kenya and the Republic of South Africa. No new species are here
   described, although dozens of candidate species have been sampled,
   mainly from Tanzania. Three genus-group names are synonymized under
   Aparopionella: Adichotrachelus Hoffmann, 1965 syn. n., Merunymus
   Hoffmann, 1965 n. syn. and Orinanchonus Voss, 1965 n. syn. Two
   subspecies are raised to full species status under Aparopionella:
   hanangensis Voss, 1965, n. stat. (from a subspecies of Orinanchonus
   lugens) and varicolor Voss, 1965, n. stat. (from a subspecies of
   Anchonidium sylvestre). One Aparopionella species-group name is a new
   junior synonym (Hoffmann's name having priority): ellipticus Hoffmann,
   1965 (Merunymus) = lugens Voss, 1965 (Orinanchonus), n. syn. Ten new
   combinations are proposed: Aparopionella angulicollis (Voss, 1965) n.
   comb. (from Anchonidium), A. elliptica (Hoffmann, 1965) n. comb. (from
   Merunymus), A. esau (Voss, 1965) n. comb. (from Orinanchonus), A.
   hanangensis (Voss, 1965) n. comb. (from Orinanchonus), A. kenyae
   (Hoffmann, 1965) n. comb. (from Adichotrachelus), A. subcostata (Voss,
   1965) n. comb. (from Orinanchonus), A. sylvestre (Voss, 1965) n. comb.
   (from Anchonidium), A. sylvicola (Voss, 1965) n. comb. (from
   Tosolophus), A. uniformis (Voss, 1974) n. comb. (from Anchonidium), and
   A. varicolor (Voss, 1965) n. comb. (from Anchonidium).
C1 Grebennikov, Vastly V.; Canadian Food Inspect Agcy, KW Neatby Bldg,960
   Carling Ave, Ottawa, ON, K1A 0Y9, Canada, Canada.
EM vasily.grebennikov@inspection.gc.ca
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835

   position; Land zones

   re-definition].

   Curculionidae

   Transferred with status upgrading from Anchonidium sylvestre, p. 229].

   Aparopionella, p. 227].

AB Two new alpine species of Nebriini from the Tibetan Plateau are
   described and figured: Nebria (Asionebria) loebliana n. sp. from
   Tanggula pass (5200 m a.s.l.) in the Tanggula Shan mountain range, and
   N. (A.) lhachenica n. sp. from the Lhachen La pass (5150-5250 m
   a.s.l.),Nyaincientanglha Shan mountain range. The gonoxocae of six
   Asionebria species are illustrated for the first time. An update to the
   key for the subgenus Asionebria is given.

DT Article
TI The first species of the genus Platychora Erichson, 1843 from the
   Australian Region (Coleoptera, Nitidulidae, Prometopinae).
AU Jelinek, Josef (jj.nitidula@seznam.cz) 
   Hajek, Jiri
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 255-261
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Platychora loebli n. sp. from the Arfak Mountains, West Papua,
   Indonesia, is described, illustrated and compared with other species of
   the genus, namely P glabra Jelinek, 1982 from Malaysia and Sumatra, with
   which it shares the glabrous dorsum. It is the first species of the
   genus Platychora Erichson, 1843 known from New Guinea, and the
   Australian region. Morphological characters, e.g. the directly forward
   projecting mandibles of males, suggest a relationship of the new species
   with its Oriental congeners.
C1 Jelinek, Josef; Natl Museum, Dept Entomol, Cirkusova 1740, Prague,
   CZ-19300, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM jj.nitidula@seznam.cz

   region; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI Notes on certain Himalayan species of the genus Trichotichnus, with
   description of a new species from Nepal (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Harpalini).
AU Kataev, Boris M. (harpal@zin.ru) 
   Schmidt, Joachim
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 263-280
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Trichotichnus (Bottchrus) ivani n. sp. is described from eastern Nepal
   (type locality: W above Gurja, 2100-2500 m, Taplejung District). Four
   species, T (s. str.) liparus Andrewes, 1926 (= T distinctus Ito, 2016,
   n. syn.), T (s. str.) aquilo Andrewes, 1930, T (s. str.) emarginatus
   Andrewes, 1930, and T (s. str.) glabellus Andrewes, 1930 are
   re-described and new data on their distribution are provided. An
   additional record of T (Bottchrus) martensi Kataev & Schmidt, 2017 from
   eastern Nepal is also given. Additional justification for the synonymy
   of several taxa of Trichotichnus originally published in the Catalogue
   of Palaearctic Coleoptera, volume 1 (2017) is also provided. Lectotypes
   are designated for T liparus Andrewes, 1926, T aquilo Andrewes, 1930 and
   T glabellus Andrewes, 1930.
C1 Kataev, Boris M.; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, St Petersburg, 199034,
   Russia, Russia.
EM harpal@zin.ru

   Synonymy; Land zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Asia; China

   [New record]. 
   Trichotichnus (Trichotichnus) aquilo - Andrews 1930 (Carabidae):
   [Redescription, P. 273; New record].

   synonym, Of Trichotichnus (Trichotichnus) glabellus Andrews 1930, p.
   279].

   [Redescription, P. 278].

TI The genus Contacyphon Gozis, 1886 in Nepal, with the description of a
   new species (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
FT Zur Kenntnis der in Nepal vorkommenden Arten der Gattung Contacyphon
   Gozis, 1886 mit Beschreibung einer neuen Art (Coleoptera, Scirtidae).
AU Klausnitzer, Bernhard (klausnitzer.col@t-online.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 287-291
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Contacyphon, Contacyphon ivanloebli n. sp., is
   described from Nepal and compared to Contacyphon nepalensis Yoshitomi,
   2009 and C. sadanarii Yoshitomi, 2009. The new species is placed in the
   Contacyphon erythrinus-subgroup of the Contacyphon coarctatus-group. A
   catalogue of the Contacyphon species presently known from Nepal is
   provided.

TI Bembidion (Peryphus) tricuspis n. sp. from Iran (Coleoptera, Carabidae,
   Bembidiini).
AU Neri, Paolo (nerolit@alice.it) 
   Toledano, Luca
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 309-312
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Bembidion (Peryphus) tricuspis n. sp. from Iran is here described and
   compared with the other species of the subgenus Peryphus Dejean, 1821,
   pars "unicolor" (elytra dark brown, blackish or black species),
   occurring in Iran and neighbouring nations (Georgia, Armenia,
   Azerbaijan, Turkey, Iraq, Iran, Southern Pakistan, Afghanistan,
   Turkmenistan). An overlooked record of B. (P.) cordicolle Jacquelin
   duVal, 1852 for Bulgaria is reported.

AN ZOOR15503014482
DT Article
TI A new species of Microcharidius Coiffait, 1969 from southwestern Iberian
   Peninsula, with reduced anterior umbilicate series (Coleoptera,
   Carabidae, Anillini).
AU Perez-Gonzalez, Sergio (seper01@ucm.es) 
   Zaballos, Juan P.
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 313-321
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Microcharidius from the province of Caceres is
   described as M loebli n. sp. It belongs to the belenae clade, and is the
   third known species of Typhlocharina with a reduced pattern of three
   setae (instead of four) in the anterior umbilicate series. It is also
   the fourth species with sexual dimorphism in the apical denticles of the
   elytra. The new species is also recognized by the presence of a very
   elongated spermathecal duct, leading to a comparison of this feature
   within the belenae clade. Another variable trait of the female
   genitalia, tergite VIII, is examined and its diversity within this clade
   is presented. The implications of the new species for the taxonomy and
   systematics of the belenae clade are discussed.
C1 Perez-Gonzalez, Sergio; Univ Complutense Madrid, Fac Biol, C Jose
   Antonio Novais 12, Madrid, E-28040, Spain, Spain.
EM seper01@ucm.es
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; General morphology; Land zones;
   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Microcharidius belenae group [General morphology /  / Systematics;
   significance of new species]. 
   Microcharidius loebli [Spain /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Microcharidius belenae group (Carabidae). 
   Microcharidius loebli (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Spain, P. 314]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15503014482
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI New taxonomic and distributional data for Madagascan and Oriental
   species of Brachypophloeus Fairmaire, 1897, with the description of B.
   ivani n. sp. from Sulawesi (Coleoptera Tenebrionidae Ulomini).
AU Schawaller, Wolfgang (schawaller.ehrenamt@smns-bw.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 353-360
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New taxonomic and distributional data for Madagascan and Oriental
   species of Brachypophloeus Fairmaire, 1897, figures of all but one
   species, and an identification key are given. B. ivani n. sp. from
   Sulawesi is described. New synonyms: Brachypophloeus elongatus (Pic,
   1922) = B. subviolaceus (Kaszab, 1980) n. syn.; Brachypophloeus
   lignicola (Gravely, 1915) = B. bifasciatus (Pic, 1922) n. syn. = B.
   forticornis (Pic, 1922) n. syn.; Brachypophloeus tonkineus (Pic, 1926) =
   B. subpubescens (Gebien, 1921) n. syn. Lectotypes are designated for
   Hypophloeus dimidiatipennis Fairmaire, 1880, Stenoscapha spissicornis
   Fairmaire, 1884, Leptoscapha elongata Pic, 1922, Leptoscapha bifasciata
   Pic, 1922, Leptoscapha forticornis Pic, 1922, Leptoscapha pulchra
   Graveley, 1915, and Leptoscapha reducta Pic, 1922. In the Madagascan
   species, the aedeagal basale is strongly bent in lateral view, in the
   Oriental species the basale is only weakly bent. This is not considered
   as a genus-level difference. B. ivani n. sp. from Sulawesi is most
   similar in external characters to B. dimidiatipennis from Madagascar.
C1 Schawaller, Wolfgang; Staatl Museum Nat, Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart,
   D-70191, Germany, Germany.
EM schawaller.ehrenamt@smns-bw.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835

   Key; Land zones; Afrotropical region; Oriental region; Africa; Eurasia;
   Asia

   Distribution; new record; systematics] [Madagascar /  / ]. 
   Brachypophloeus ivani [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Brachypophloeus pulcher [Bhutan /  / New record; systematics].

   Tenebrionidae

   Oriental region, P. 359; New record].

   Leptoscapha subviolacea Kaszab 1980, p. 355]. 
   Brachypophloeus ivani (Tenebrionidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 357]. 
   Brachypophloeus lignicola - (Gravely 1915) (Tenebrionidae): [Syn nov,
   Leptoscapha bifasciata Pic 1922, p. 358; Syn nov, Leptoscapha
   forticornis Pic 1922, p. 358]. 
   Brachypophloeus pulcher - Gravely 1915 (Tenebrionidae): [New record].

DT Article
TI Alpha-taxonomy from the Himalaya-Tibet orogen: New species and new
   synonymies in Bembidion Latreille, and a new key to species of the
   subgenus Bembidionetolitzkya Strand (Coleoptera, Carabidae, Bembidiini).
AU Schmidt, Joachim (schmidt@agonum.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 361-406
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB 20 new species and two new subspecies of Bembidion Latreille, 1802
   ground beetles are described from the Greater Himalaya, the Tibetan
   Himalaya, the Transhimalaya, and the southern Tibetan Plateau. The
   following new taxa are described within the subgenus Bembidionetolitzkya
   Strand, 1929: B. lunepabomaguvi n. sp. from Arunachal Pradesh (India),
   with the subspecies B. 1. bhutanicum n. ssp. from the Bhutan; B.
   chaklaense n. sp., B. pinnigerum n. sp., B. retingense n. sp., and B.
   transhimalayanum n. sp. from the central Transhimalaya (South Tibet,
   China); B. lhai n. sp. from the southern slope of the Nyaincientanglha
   Shan (South Tibet, China); B. namtso n. sp. from the northern slope of
   the Nyaingentanglha Shan; B. smetanai qingmaiense n. ssp. from
   southwestern Yunnan (China); B. zugmayeri n. sp. from West Tibet
   (China). A key to the 42 Bembidionetolitzkya species currently known to
   occur in the Himalaya-Tibet orogen is presented. Bembidion praeceptor n.
   sp. is described as the first representative of the subgenus Josefia
   Toledano, 2000 in the Transhimalaya of southern Central Tibet. Three new
   species are described within the subgenus Ocyturanes Muller-Motzfeld,
   1986: B. christophi n. sp. and B. lhatseense n. sp. from the central
   Tibetan Himalaya, and B. gracilipenne n. ssp. from the central
   Transhimalaya. Four new species are described within the subgenus
   Peryphus Dejean, 1821: B. ahrensi n. sp., B. aparupa n. sp., B.
   dhaulagiricum n. sp., and B. glabripenne n. sp., all from West Nepal.
   The subgenus Politophanes Muller-Motzfeld is removed from synonymy with
   Peryphus, and one species is described herein: B. inventor n. sp. from
   East Nepal. One species is described within the subgenus Terminophanes
   Muller-Motzfeld, 1998: B. reibnitzi n. sp. from the Yarlung Zhangbo
   Valley in South Tibet. Two species are described within the subgenus
   Peryphophila Netolitzky, 1939: B. problematicum n. sp. and B.
   pseudoclarum n. sp. from Nepal; the latter also occurs in Bhutan and
   Thailand. The following 16 new synonymies are proposed (senior synonym
   listed first): Bembidion (Peryphus) bracculatum Bates, 1889 = B.
   ladakense Andrewes, 1924 n. syn. = B. rubidum Andrewes, 1924 n. syn. =
   B. hazara Andrewes, 1935 n. syn. = B. ladakense baumi Muller-Motzfeld,
   1985 n. syn. = B. ladakense naltarense Muller-Motzfeld, 1988 n. syn.;
   Bembidion (Peryphus) insidiosum luntaka Andrewes, 1924 = B. betegara
   Andrewes, 1924 n. syn. = B. ixion Andrewes, 1934 n. syn. = B. clops
   Andrewes, 1935 n. syn. = B. ledouxianum Kirschenhofer, 1989, n. syn.;
   Bembidion (Terminophanes) kashmirense Netolitzky, 1920 = B. limatum
   Andrewes, 1924 n. syn. = B. dux Andrewes, 1935 n. syn. = B. languens
   Andrewes, 1935 n. syn. = B. ochropus Andrewes, 1935 n. syn.; Bembidium
   (Terminophanes) leve Andrewes, 1924 = B. delerei Fassati, 1957 n. syn.;
   Bembidion (Politophanes) chakrata Andrewes, 1935 = B. pokharense Habu,
   1973 n. syn.; Bembidion (Politophanes) phaedrum Andrewes, 1923 = B.
   politer Andrewes, 1935 n. syn. Bembidion (Politophanes) purkynei
   Jedlieka, 1932 rest. stat. is removed from synonymy with B. phaedrum
   Andrewes, 1923.
C1 Schmidt, Joachim; Univ Rostock, Zool Inst, Univ Pl 2, Rostock, D-18055,
   Germany, Germany.
EM schmidt@agonum.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Key; Land
   zones; Oriental region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China; India
DE Bembidion [Asia / Himalaya-Tibet orogen / Systematics]. 
   Bembidion (Bembidionetolitzkya) [Asia / Himalaya-Tibet orogen / Key to
   species & subspecies].

   (Bembidionetolitzkya) lhai; Bembidion (Bembidionetolitzkya) namtso;

   Bembidion (Ocyturanes) christophi (Carabidae): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 384].

   Bembidion (Peryphus) - Dejean 1821 (Carabidae): [Removal from synonymy,

PT J
AN ZOOR15503014488
DT Article
TI Two new species and new records of Acolastus Gerstaecker from the
   Arabian Peninsula (Coleoptera, Chrysomelidae, Cryptocephalinae).
AU Schoeller, Matthias (Matthias.Schoeller@hu-berlin.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 407-413
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of Acolastus s. str. from the Arabian Peninsula are
   described, i.e. A. loebli n. sp. from Oman, and A. callosomarginatus n.
   sp. from Yemen. The new species are similar to A. substriatus (Medvedev,
   1996) and A. furthi (Lopatin, 1994). The new species are illustrated and
   an updated key to the Acolastus species from the Arabian Peninsula is
   provided. New records for Acolastus spp. from the Arabian Peninsula are
   added. Acolastus latifrons Lopatin & Nesterova, 2007 is recorded for the
   first time from Oman.
C1 Schoeller, Matthias; Humboldt Univ Berlin, Fac Life Sci, Lentzeallee
   55-57, Berlin, D-14195, Germany, Germany.
EM Matthias.Schoeller@hu-berlin.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   Systematics]. 
   Acolastus (Acolastus) callosomarginatus [Yemen /  / New species]. 
   Acolastus (Acolastus) loebli [Oman /  / New species]. 
   Acolastus latifrons [Oman /  / New record]. 
   Acolastus wittmeri [Oman / Al Batinah South Province / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Chrysomeloidea,
   Chrysomelidae

   Arabian Peninsula, Updated key, p. 412].

   P. 410].

   Acolastus latifrons (Chrysomelidae): [New record]. 
   Acolastus wittmeri (Chrysomelidae): [New record].

AN ZOOR15503014489
DT Article
TI Further new country records of African tiger beetles, with some
   taxonomic notes (Coleoptera, Cicindelidae).
AU Schuele, Peter (sei.schuele@gmx.de) 
   Monfort, Alain
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 415-429
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New country records for 40 species and subspecies of African tiger
   beetles are presented. Two doubtful country records could be confirmed.
   11 new synonymies are proposed: Elliptica muata parallelestriata W.
   Horn, 1923 is proposed as a junior synonym of Elliptica muata muata
   (Harold, 1878), Elliptica laticornis dispersefiavescens (W. Horn, 1913)
   and Elliptica laticornis irregularis (W. Horn, 1913) are proposed as a
   junior synonyms of Elliptica laticornis laticornis (W. Horn, 1900),
   Elliptica compressicornis persignata Cassola, 1995 is proposed as a
   junior synonym of Elliptica compressicornis compressicornis (Boheman,
   1860), Habrodera nilotica caelicolorata (Mandl, 1981) is proposed as a
   junior synonym of Habrodera nilotica nilotica (Dejean, 1825), Habrodera
   nitidula rutherfordi (Bates, 1878) is proposed as a junior synonym of
   Habrodera nitidula nitidula (Dejean, 1825), Ropaloteres nysa burgeoni
   (Basilewsky, 1948) is proposed as a junior synonym of Ropaloteres
   quedenfeldti (W. Horn, 1896), Lophyra (Bothrylophyra) pseudominax
   Wiesner, 2001 is proposed as a junior synonym of Lophyra (Bothrylophyra)
   minax (Wallengren, 1881). The synonymy of Ophryodera rufomarginata
   bradshawi (Peringuey, 1888), Ophryodera rufomarginata circumcinctoides
   (W. Horn, 1904) and Ophryodera rufomarginata oberthueri (Peringuey,
   1888) with Ophryodera rufomarginata rufomarginata (Boheman, 1848) sensu
   BASILEWSKY (1955) is confirmed. Ophryodera rufomarginata poggei (Harold,
   1878), Ophryodera rufomarginata maculatovittata (W. Horn, 1938) and
   Ophryodera rufomarginata richteri (W. Horn, 1892) are proposed as a
   junior synonyms of Ophryodera rufomarginata rufomarginata.
C1 Schuele, Peter; Rosenstr 9, Herrenberg, D-71083, Germany, Germany.
EM sei.schuele@gmx.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835

   Africa

   angusticollis angusticollis [Botswana /  / New record].

TI On the discovery of three missing Putzeys types of the genus Bembidion
   Latreille, 1802 in the collection of RBINS, Brussels, with notes on the
   South American Bembidiina (Coleoptera, Carabidae).
AU Toledano, Luca (lucatole2@libero.it) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 437-450
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The type specimens of Bembidion ovatum Putzeys, 1878, B. angulicolle
   (Putzeys, 1878) and B. basiplagiatum (Putzeys, 1878), formerly
   considered as missing, and discovered in the miscellaneous collection of
   RBINS, Brussels, are here redescribed and designated as lectotypes. The
   following species, formerly ranked as Bembidion incertae sedis are
   assigned here to subgenera of genus Bembidion: B. putzeysi Csiki, 1928,
   (replacement name for B. ovatum) assigned to the subgenus Ecuadion Moret
   & Toledano, 2002; B. angulicolle assigned to the subgenus Antiperyphanes
   Jeanne), 1962. The following new synonymies (with junior synonym listed
   first) are proposed: Bembidion (Notaphus) basiplagiatoides Toledano,
   2008 n. syn. of B. basiplagiatum Putzeys, 1878; B. riobamba Toledano,
   2008 n. syn. of B. cayambense Bates, 1891.
C1 Toledano, Luca; Museo Civ Storia Nat Verona, Lungadige Porta Vittoria 9,
   Verona, I-37129, Italy, Italy.
EM lucatole2@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Type material; Description; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Adephaga, Caraboidea,
   Carabidae
OR Bembidion (Ecuadion) putzeysi - Csiki 1928 (Carabidae): [Redescription,
   P. 442]. 
   Bembidion (Notaphus) basiplagiatum - (Putzeys 1878) (Carabidae):
   [Redescription, P. 439; Syn nov, Bembidion (Notaphus) basiplagiatoides
   Toledano 2008, p. 439]. 
   Bembidion (Notaphus) cayambense - Bates 1891 (Carabidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 440; Redescription, P. 440; Syn nov, Bembidion (Notaphus)
   riobamba Toledano 2008, p. 440]. 
   Bembidion angulicolle - (Putzeys 1878) (Carabidae): [Referred to,
   Bembidion (Antiperyphanes), p. 444]. 
   Bembidion basiplagiaturn - Putzeys 1878 (Carabidae): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 439]. 
   Bembidion ovatum - Putzeys 1878 (Carabidae): [Lectotype designated, P.
   442]. 
   Bembidion putzeysi - Csiki 1928 (Carabidae): [Referred to, Bembidion
   (Ecuadion), p. 440]. 
   Peryphus angulicollis - Putzeys 1878 (Carabidae): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 449].

DT Article
TI Remarks on the taxonomy of Tmesisternini, and the description of eleven
   new species of the genus Tmesisternus Latreille, 1829 from Western Papua
   and Sumba (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
FT Taxonomische Bemerkungen zu Tmesisternini und Beschreibung von elf neuen
   Arten der Gattung Tmesisternus Latreille, 1829 aus West -Papua und Sumba
   (Coleoptera, Cerambycidae).
AU Weigel, Andreas (rosalia-aw@online.de) 
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 451-481
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following new synonymies are proposed (senior synonym listed first):
   Tmesisternus Latreille, 1829 (type species Tmesisternus bizonulatus
   Guerin-Meneville, 1831) = Roodenburgia Withaar, 2015 n. syn. (type
   species Roodenburgia witjesi Withaar, 2015); Tmesisternus bizonulatus
   Guerin-Meneville, 1831 = Roodenburgia witjesi Withaar, 2015 n. syn.;
   Tmesisternus montanus Gressitt, 1984 = T. umboinus Withaar, 2016 n.
   syn.; Tmesisternus vagus (Thomson, 1865) = T. wajaus Withaar, 2017 n.
   syn. Roodenburgia schepmani Withaar, 2015 is newly combined in the genus
   Tmesisternus. Tmesisternus agrarius Pascoe, 1867 stat. rev. is
   considered as a species propria, with the new synonym T. ingeae Withaar,
   2017 n. syn. Taxonomic remarks are given on the Tmesisternus griseus
   group sensu GRESSITT. (1984) including T. carlae Withaar, 2017 and T.
   bosavius Withaar, 2017. Tmesisternus gebehensis Breuning & De Jong, 1941
   is considered as a subspecific taxon of T. petechialis Pascoe, 1868,
   with T. elongatus Breuning, 1945 as its synonym. Additions to the
   description of Tmesisternus planus Withaar, 2016 are presented. Ten new
   species are described from Western Papua (Indonesia): Tmesisternus
   udoschmidti n. sp., T. jakli n. sp., T. skalei n. sp., T. holzschuhi n.
   sp., T. huedepohli n. sp., T. grimmi n. sp., T. loebli n. sp., T.
   floorjansenae n. sp., T. kurima n. sp., T. gerstmeieri n. sp.; one new
   species is described from the Indonesian Island of Sumba: Tmesisternus
   telnovi n. sp.
C1 Weigel, Andreas; Schlossgarten 6, Wernburg, D-07381, Germany, Germany.
EM rosalia-aw@online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0013-8835
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Combination; Synonymy;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Status; Land zones; Australasian region;
   Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia; Australasia

   holzschuhi; Tmesisternus huedepohli; Tmesisternus jakli; Tmesisternus
   kurima; Tmesisternus loebli; Tmesisternus skalei; Tmesisternus telnovi;
   Tmesisternus udoschmidti [Indonesia /  / New species]. 
   Tmesisternus grimmi [Papua New Guinea /  / New species].

   Cerambycidae

   Tmesisternus, p. 453].

   Withaar 2015, p. 452].

   nov, Roodenburgia witjesi Withaar 2015, p. 453].

   Of Tmesisternus petechialis gebehensis Breuning & De Jong 1941, p. 454].

   Tmesisternus gerstmeieri (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 478]. 
   Tmesisternus grimmi (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Papua New Guinea, P. 468]. 
   Tmesisternus griseus agrarius - Pascoe 1868 (Cerambycidae): [Raised to,

   Tmesisternus griseus group (Cerambycidae): [Included taxa, P. 453]. 
   Tmesisternus holzschuhi (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 464]. 
   Tmesisternus huedepohli (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 466]. 
   Tmesisternus jakli (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 459]. 
   Tmesisternus kurima (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 473]. 
   Tmesisternus loebli (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 469]. 
   Tmesisternus lotor gebehensis - Breuning & De Jong 1941 (Cerambycidae):
   [Referred to, Tmesisternus petechialis gebehensis Breuning & De Jong
   1941, p. 454]. 
   Tmesisternus montanus - Gressitt 1984 (Cerambycidae): [Syn nov,
   Tmesisternus umboinus Withaar 2016, p. 453]. 
   Tmesisternus petechialis gebehensis - Breuning & De Jong 1941
   (Cerambycidae): [Senior synonym, Of Tmesisternus elongatus Breuning
   1945, p. 454; Transferred from, Tmesisternus lotor gebehensis Breuning &
   De Jong 1941, p. 454]. 
   Tmesisternus planus - Withaar 2016 (Cerambycidae): [Redescription, P.
   455]. 
   Tmesisternus schepmani - (Withaar 2015) (Cerambycidae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Roodenburgia, p. 453]. 
   Tmesisternus skalei (Cerambycidae): [Sp nov, Indonesia, P. 460].

TI The genus Scydmobisetia Jaloszyfiski & Yamamoto, 2016 in Upper
   Cretaceous Burmese amber (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Scydmaeninae).
AU Yin, Ziwei (pselaphinae@gmail.com) 
   Zhou, Deyao
   Cai, Chenyang
SO Entomologische Blaetter fuer Biologie und Systematik der Kaefer
VL 114
PS 483-490
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of the extinct genus Scydmobisetia Jaloszyfiski &
   Yamamoto, S. loebli n. sp. and S. mengjiae n. sp., are described from
   mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber. Both new species can be readily
   distinguished from their sole congener, S. vetutissima Jaloszynski &
   Yamamoto, by their different body size, proportions of the antennomeres,
   and modifications of legs in the male. The sex of the holotype of S.
   vetutissima is briefly discussed, and a supplementary description of
   this species is provided. An identification key to species of
   Scydmobisetia is presented. Our finding highlights the diversity of a
   poorly-known group of Scydmaeninae during the late Mesozoic.

DT Article
TI The Ordovician and Silurian conodonts of Japan: Their biostratigraphical
   and paleobiogeographical significance.
AU Mannik, Peep (peep.mannik@ttu.ee) 
   Maekawa, Takumi
   Tanaka, Gengo
   Komatsu, Toshifumi
   Siveter, David
   Williams, Mark
   Hints, Olle
   Vandenbroucke, Thijs R.A.
SO Island Arc
VL 27
IS 6
PS e12269
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Conodont-bearing Ordovician and Silurian rocks have a wide geographical
   distribution in Japan. They are exposed on Honshu, Shikoku, and Kyushu
   islands. Two recently studied samples from Gionyama, in Kyushu, yield
   conodont assemblages of Telychian (Distomodus sp., Apsidognathus sp.
   (cf. A. tuberculatus arcticus), Oulodus cf. rectangulus, Ozarkodina cf.
   waugoolaensis, Panderodus cf. amplicostatus) and probably the earliest
   Sheinwoodian (?Distomodus sp. (cf. D. staurognathoides), Ozarkodina sp.,
   Oulodus sp., Walliserodus sp. (cf. Walliserodus sp. nov. c Mannik),
   Panderodus sp.) ages, providing further biostratigraphical constraints
   for the age of the Gionyama Formation in the Kurosegawa Terrane. Most of
   the conodont taxa identified have wide paleobiogeographical
   distribution, but probable occurrence of Oulodus rectangulus, Ozarkodina
   waugoolaensis, and Panderodus amplicostatus suggests a relationship
   between Australia, the South China paleocontinent, and the Kurosegawa
   Terrane of 'Proto-Japan' during the Silurian. These paleogeographic
   interpretations agree with the existing notions based on rugose corals.

   Estonia, Estonia.
EM peep.mannik@ttu.ee

DT Article
TI Molecular evidence of sexual polymorphism in the rare deep-sea lobster
   genus Thaumastocheles Wood-Mason, 1874 (Crustacea: Decapoda:
   Nephropidae).
AU Chang, Su-Ching
   Chan, Tin-Yam (tychan@mail.ntou.edu.tw) 
SO Journal of Crustacean Biology
VL 38
IS 6
PS 772-779
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The rare deep-sea lobsters of the genus Thaumastocheles Wood-Mason, 1874
   are characterized by having conspicuously unequal first chelipeds, with
   the right cheliped greatly elongated and pectinate. The five species of
   Thaumastocheles are mainly separated by the shape of the teeth in the
   major chelae. Molecular analysis using four genetic markers (three
   mitochondrial: COI, 12S rDNA, 16S rDNA; one nuclear: ITS-1) on an
   extensive series of the species of Thaumastocheles from different
   localities reveals that there is sexual dimorphism and even male
   polymorphism in the major chelae in at least half of the species, with
   T. dochmiodon Chan & de Saint Laurent, 1999 being the male form in T.
   japonicus Calman, 1913. Thaumastocheles dochmiodon is therefore
   considered a junior synonym of T. japonicus. The other species confirmed
   as showing sexual dimorphism and male polymorphism is T. massonktenos
   Chang, Chan & Ahyong, 2014. A revised key is provided for the species of
   Thaumastocheles. Whether sexual dimorphism and male polymorphism are
   common phenomena in Thaumastocheles or even all thaumastocheliforms
   still awaits the collection and discovery of additional material of both
   sexes.
C1 Chan, Tin-Yam; Natl Taiwan Ocean Univ, Inst Marine Biol, Keelung, 20224,
   Taiwan, Taiwan.
EM tychan@mail.ntou.edu.tw
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Reproductive Biology; Genetics
   &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0278-0372

   region; Eurasia; Asia

DT Article
TI A New Species of Luminous Percoids of the Acropoma Genus
   (Acropomatidae).
AU Prokofiev, A.M. (prokartster@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Ichthyology
VL 58
IS 6
PS 939-943
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species, Acropoma leobergi sp. n. from the Arafura Sea, belonging
   to a group of species with a short U-shaped luminous organ slightly
   receding behind the anus, is described. From other species of this
   group, the described species is well distinguished by a combination of
   such features as a small number of gill rakers in the outer row on the
   first arc (18-20), the presence of the chin boss, the presence of
   cycloid scales on the sides of the body, four longitudinal rows of
   scales between the beginning of the first dorsal fin and lateral line,
   and dense melanophore pigmentation on the dorsal surface of the luminous
   organ. Earlier representatives of this species, apparently, were
   mistakenly identified with the northwestern Pacific species A.japonicum
   (from Japan to Vietnam and the Philippines). A new synonymy was
   established: Acropoma lacrima Okamoto et Golani, 2017 = A. splendens
   (Lloyd, 1909).

PM 30367870
DT Article
TI Morphology and molecular systematic of marine gregarines (Apicomplexa)
   from Southwestern Atlantic spionid polychaetes.
AU Rueckert, S.
   Glasinovich, N.
   Diez, M.E.
   Cremonte, F.
   Vazquez, N. (nuria@cenpat-conicet.gob.ar) 
SO Journal of Invertebrate Pathology
VL 159
PS 49-60
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Gregarines are a common group of parasites that infect the intestines of
   marine invertebrates, and particularly polychaetes. Here, we describe
   for the first time four gregarine species that inhabit the intestines of
   three spionid species: Dipolydora cf. flava, Spio quadrisetosa and
   Boccardia Proboscidea from the Patagonian coast, Argentina, using light
   and scanning electron microscopy and molecular phylogenetic analyses of
   small subunit (SSU) rDNA sequences. Even though the spionid species
   thrive in the same environments, our results showed a high host
   specificity of the gregarine species. Selenidium cf. axiferens and
   Polyrhabdina aff. polydorae were both identified from the intestine of
   D. cf. flava. The new species, Polyrhabdina madrynense sp. n. and
   Selenidium patagonica sp. n., were described from the intestines of S.
   quadrisetosa and the invasive species B. Proboscidea, respectively. All
   specimens of D. cf. flava and S. quadrisetosa were infected by
   gregarines (P = 100%), recording the highest mean intensity values of
   infection (MI = 80; 60 respectively), in contrast to B. Proboscidea (P =
   60%; MI = 38). We associated this finding with the recent invasion of
   this host. It is expected that in the future, an increase of its
   population density might favour a rising intensity of this gregarine
   infection.

PM 30300631
DT Article
TI Molecular and structural assessment of microsporidia infecting daphnids:
   The 'obtusa-like' microsporidia, a branch of the monophyletic
   Agglomeratidae Glade, with the establishment of a new genus
   Conglomerata.
AU Vavra, Jiri
   Fiala, Ivan
   Krylova, Pavia
   Petrusek, Adam
   Hylis, Miroslav (miroslav.hylis@natur.cuni.cz) 
SO Journal of Invertebrate Pathology
VL 159
PS 95-104
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 3
U2 14
AB Microsporidia (Opisthosporidia, Microsporidia) are frequent parasites of
   planktonic cladocerans, including Daphnia (Crustacea, Branchiopoda).
   Analysis of available molecular data (ITS region and partial ssu and lsu
   rDNA) of these parasites indicates that many microsporidia infecting
   daphnids have a common ancestor and represent a large Glade, which
   splits during evolution into a number of well supported subclades. These
   subclades are cytologically different but may be most conveniently
   characterised by their specific ITS barcode. We have analysed one of
   these subclades and we describe a new microsporidian genus and species
   combination, and assemble a large group of structurally
   indistinguishable microsporidian parasites that infect adipose cells of
   their hosts and form pyriform spores of a certain type ("obtuse
   spores"). Obtuse spores are non-infectious by feeding to their
   crustacean hosts and it is plausible that microsporidia forming them
   actually are parasites of insects with aquatic larval stages, with an
   obligate two-host life cycle, analogous to the Amblyospora life cycle
   involving copepods and mosquitoes.

DT Article
TI Molecular phylogeny of Ischnocnema (Anura: Brachycephalidae) with the
   redefinition of its series and the description of two new species.
AU Taucce, Pedro P.G. (pedrotaucce@gmail.com) 
   Canedo, Clarissa
   Parreiras, Julia Soares
   Drummond, Leandro O.
   Nogueira-Costa, Paulo
   Haddad, Celio F.B.
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 128
PS 123-146
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB We present a new phylogenetic hypothesis for Ischnocnema, a Neotropical
   brachycephaloid genus of ground-dwelling direct-developing frogs. We
   performed Bayesian inference, maximum likelihood, and maximum parsimony
   analyses using two nuclear (RAG1 and Tyr) and three mitochondrial genes
   (12S rRNA, tRNA-Val, and 16S rRNA) in a matrix comprising more than 80%
   of the described species. We recover Ischnocnema nanahallux outside the
   Ischnocnema parva series, and it is now unassigned to any species
   series, nor are Ischnocnema manezinho and Ischnocnema sambaqui. We
   propose the Ischnocnema venancioi species series to comprise Ischnocnema
   venancioi, Ischnocnema hoehnei, and two new species described herein
   (Ischnocnema parnaso sp. nov. and Ischnocnema colibri sp. nov.).
   Furthermore, we designate a lectotype for I. venancioi. The nuptial pad
   present in males is an important character in the genus, and having a
   large, conspicuous, and glandular-appearing nuptial pad seems to be a
   synapomorphy for the Glade composed of the I. parva, Ischnocnema
   guentheri, and the newly proposed I. venancioi series.
C1 Taucce, Pedro P.G.; UNESP Univ Estadual Paulista, Inst Biociencias,

DT Article
TI Clarifying the phylogenetic relationships and taxonomy of Stenonema,
   Stenacron and Maccaffertium, three common eastern North American mayfly
   genera.
AU Zembrzuski, Deanna C.
   Anderson, Frank E. (dzembrzu@asu.edu) 
SO Molecular Phylogenetics and Evolution
VL 128
PS 212-220
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 2
U2 14
AB Stenonema, Stenacron, and Maccaffertium are three closely related genera
   of mayflies (Ephemeroptera: Heptageniidae) commonly found across North
   America. Due to their primarily aquatic life history and sensitivity to
   aquatic pollutants, these mayflies are often used as water quality
   indicators. However, there is little morphological variation within
   these genera, leading to difficulties in identification and rampant
   taxonomic confusion, limiting their utility as bioindicators. In an
   attempt to resolve the phylogenetic relationships of Stenonema,
   Stenacron, and Maccaffertium, and to clarify their higher-level
   classifications, we sequenced regions of two mitochondrial genes
   (cytochrome oxidase subunit 1 (cox1) and 16S ribosomal RNA (rrnl)) and
   two nuclear genes (Wingless (Wg) and histone H3) from 60 individuals
   representing most of the described species in these genera and included
   data from representatives of three heptageniid genera (Kageronia,
   Macdunnoa and Pseudiron) proposed in previous studies to be closely
   related to our focal taxa as well as two more distantly related
   heptageniid genera (Epeorus and Heptagenia) to root the phylogenies.
   Maximum likelihood and Bayesian analysis were conducted on single-gene
   and concatenated multi-gene data sets and species tree methods were
   utilized to resolve relationships. These analyses resolved Stenacron as
   a monophyletic group sister to a Glade comprising Macdunnoa,
   Maccaffertium and Stenonema. Maccaffertium was found to be paraphyletic,
   with Stenonema femoratum resolved within Maccaffertium as sister to M.
   mexicanum. Many relationships remained unresolved or varied across
   analyses, making revision of the classification based on phylogenetic
   considerations challenging. To minimize confusion while naming clades
   and acknowledging uncertainty in our phylogenetic conclusions, we
   redefine Stenonema to include Maccaffertium and propose three
   subgenera-Stenonema, Maccaffertium and Lewisa- for key well-supported
   clades.
C1 Anderson, Frank E.; Southern Illinois Univ, Dept Zool, Carbondale, IL,
   62901, USA, USA.
EM dzembrzu@asu.edu
OI Anderson, Frank/0000-0002-5786-0314
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology
SN 1055-7903
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Biochemistry; Genetics; Evolution
DE Maccaffertium; Stenacron; Stenonema [Nucleic acids / mtCOI & 16S rRNA
   sequnces / systematics] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ].

DT Article
TI New Vendian Saarinid Microorganisms from the Siberian Platform.
AU Kolosov, P.N. (p_kolosov@diamond.ysn.ru) 
   Sofroneeva, L.S.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 589-592
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB Vendian (Ediacaran) tubiform organic-walled segmented microfossils from
   the East Siberian Platform, with no biological interpretation, were
   previously assigned to the Incertae sedis genus Kursovia Kolosov et
   Rudavskaja, 1984 and identified as Kursovia sp. 4. The re-examination of
   these fossils showed that these are new saarinid microorganisms that
   resemble Saarina juliae in the tubiform shape, segmented structure,
   presence of crenulae on free (upper) edge of segments and in the
   prominence of these features, but are smaller by one-two orders of
   magnitude. They are herein assigned to a new genus and species
   Saarinomorpha infundibularis Kolosov et Sofroneeva, gen. et sp. nov. in
   the family Saarinidae Sokolov, 1965.
C1 Kolosov, P.N.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Yakutsk, 677891,
   Russia, Russia.
EM p_kolosov@diamond.ysn.ru

   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Precambrian

   Saarinomorpha infundibularis [Russia /  / new species] [Proterozoic /  /

ST Animalia
OR Saarinomorpha (Animalia): [Gen nov, Of family Saarinidae, Type species

TI The First Data on Bryozoans from the Lyaiol Formation (Upper Devonian,
   Upper Frasnian) in South Timan.
AU Tolokonnikova, Z.A. (zalatoi@yandex.ru) 
   Ponomarenko, E.S.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 593-598
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB For the first time the systematic composition of the bryozoan assemblage
   from the Lyaiol Formation (Upper Frasnian, Upper Devonian) in the Ukhta
   region of the Timan-Pechora province is described. The assemblage
   consists of eight species, including one new species, Neotrematopora
   lyaoilensis sp. nov., and seven species left in open nomenclature. The
   bryozoans are represented by cosmopolitan genera common in the Frasnian
   of Eurasia and North America.

TI Bryozoa (Stenolaemata) from the Upper Callovian (Middle Jurassic) of the
   Moscow Region.
AU Viskova, L.A. (l_viskova@mail.ru) 
   Pakhnevich, A.V.
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 599-609
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three species of incrusting bryozoans (Tubuliporida, Stenolaemata) from
   the Upper Callovian (Middle Jurassic) in the vicinity of the town of
   Kolomna, Moscow region, are described: Stomatopora dichotoma (Lamouroux,
   1821), which was first discovered in the late Callovian of the Moscow
   region; Reptomultisparsa stratosa sp. nov.; and ?Microeciella sp. Some
   features of the interaction between S. dichotoma and ?Microeciella sp.
   the colonies of which developed side by side on the same substrate are
   discussed.

DT Article
TI New Beetles (Insecta, Coleoptera) from the Upper Vyatkian Aristovo
   Locality, European Russia.
AU Ponomarenko, A.G. (aponom@paleo.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 620-630
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Fossil beetles of the families Asiocoleidae, Schizocoleidae, and
   Permosynidae, recently collected in the Aristovo locality (Upper
   Permian, northern European Russia, Malaya Northern Dvina River) are
   described. All fossils are isolated elytra, whose systematic position in
   the natural system is often hardly established; thus, they are described
   as formal taxa. Aristovo is the only locality dominated by both
   asiocoleids and permosynids; these insects started playing an important
   role at the end of the Permian. It could also have adephagians and
   polyphagyans, the main groups of Meso-Cainozoic beetles.

   117647, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI A New Genus and Species of Stromateoid Fishes (Perciformes,
   Stromateoidei) from the Lower Oligocene of the Northern Caucasus.
AU Bannikov, A.F. (aban@paleo.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 631-638
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A stromateoid fish, Cubariomma yanakuzminae gen. et sp. nov.
   (Perciformes), from the Lower Maikopian (Lower Oligocene) of the
   Northern Caucasus (Adygea, Belaya River) is described based on an
   incomplete skeleton and several fragments. Judging from the characters
   available for the study, the new genus is similar to some genera from
   the families Nomeidae and Ariommatidae. The fishes of these two families
   closely resemble each other in general appearance and osteology,
   differing mostly in the structure of their pharyngeal sacs. The
   preservation of Cubariomma yanakuzminae gen. et sp. nov. precludes
   unequivocal classification within either Nomeidae or Ariommatidae; thus,
   the new taxon is left incertae sedis within the Stromateoidei. A review
   of the fossil record of Stromateoidei sensu stricto is provided.
C1 Bannikov, A.F.; Russian Acad Sci, Borissiak Paleontol Inst, Moscow,
   117647, Russia, Russia.
EM aban@paleo.ru
RI Bannikov, Alexander F./P-9902-2015

   Eurasia; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

   Cubariomma yanakuzminae [Russia /  / new species] [Oligocene /  / ]. 
   Stromateoidei [Geological time periods /  / Review of fossil record].

DT Article
TI Morphology, Systematics, and Stratigraphic Significance of the Dinocyst
   Genus Dingodinium.
AU Pestchevitskaya, E.B. (PeschevickayaEB@ipgg.sbras.ru) 
SO Paleontological Journal
VL 52
IS 6
PS 682-696
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB New material from the Upper Kimmeridgian and Volgian of the Gorodishche
   section (Ulyanovsk Region, Russia) allows a more accurate definition of
   the tabulation formula and archeopyle morphology of the dinocyst genus
   Dingodinium. The partiform pattern of the antapex and morphological
   features of the epicyst indicate that the genus Dingodinium should be
   attributed to the family Cladopyxiaceae of the suborder Cladopyxiineae.
   The genus Dingodinium as well as the species D. albertii, D. jurassicum,
   and D. tuberosum are revised, and a new species, D. nequeas, is
   described. In addition, the published data on Jurassic and Cretaceous
   species of the genus Dingodinium are analyzed and morphological criteria
   allowing their identification are recognized. Many species have a wide
   geographic distribution. Some species can be regarded as
   stratigraphically important for certain intervals of the Jurassic and
   Cretaceous.

   Geophys, Novosibirsk, 630090, Russia, Russia.

DT Article
TI CYP-mediated permethrin resistance in Aedes aegypti and evidence for
   trans-regulation.
AU Smith, Leticia B.
   Tyagi, Rakshit
   Kasai, Shinji
   Scott, Jeffrey G. (jgs5@cornell.edu) 
SO PLoS Neglected Tropical Diseases
VL 12
IS 11
PS e000693
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB Aedes aegypti poses a serious risk to human health due to its wide
   global distribution, high vector competence for several arboviruses,
   frequent human biting, and ability to thrive in urban environments.
   Pyrethroid insecticides remain the primary means of controlling adult A.
   aegypti populations during disease outbreaks. As a result of decades of
   use, pyrethroid resistance is a global problem. Cytochrome P450
   monooxygenase (CYP)-mediated detoxification is one of the primary
   mechanisms of pyrethroid resistance. However, the specific CYP(s)
   responsible for resistance have not been unequivocally determined. We
   introgressed the resistance alleles from the resistant A. aegypti
   strain, Singapore (SP), into the genetic background of the susceptible
   ROCK strain. The resulting strain (CKR) was congenic to ROCK. Our
   primary goal was to determine which CYPs in SP are linked to resistance.
   To do this, we first determined which CYPs overexpressed in SP are also
   overexpressed in CKR, with the assumption that only the CYPs linked to
   resistance will be overexpressed in CKR relative to ROCK. Next, we
   determined whether any of the overexpressed CYPs were genetically linked
   to resistance (cis-regulated) or not (trans-regulated). We found that
   CYP6BB2, CYP6Z8, CYP9M5 and CYP9M6 were overexpressed in SP as well as
   in CKR. Based on the genomic sequences and polymorphisms of five single
   copy CYPs (CYP4C50, 6BB2, 6F2, 6F3 and 6Z8) in each strain, none of
   these genes were linked to resistance, except for CYP6BB2, which was
   partially linked to the resistance locus. Hence, overexpression of these
   four CYPs is due to a trans-regulatory factor(s). Knowledge on the
   specific CYPs and their regulators involved in resistance is critical
   for resistance management strategies because it aids in the development
   of new control chemicals, provides information on potential
   environmental modulators of resistance, and allows for the detection of
   resistance markers before resistance becomes fixed in the population.
C1 Scott, Jeffrey G.; Cornell Univ, Dept Entomol, Comstock Hall, Ithaca,
   NY, 14853, USA, USA.
EM jgs5@cornell.edu
RI Smith, Leticia Barion/AAU-3318-2020
OI Smith, Leticia Barion/0000-0002-8798-326X
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular
   Biology; Genetics &Heredity
SN 1935-2727; 1935-2735
BD Animals and man; Control; Biochemistry; Proteins; Genetics; Molecular
   genetics; Abiotic factors; Chemical factors
DE Aedes aegypti [Chemical control / Permethrin resistance / ] [Nucleic
   acids / Cytochrome P450 monooxygenase genes / ] [Enzymes /  / ]
   [Genotype /  / ] [Gene expression /  / ] [Fertilizers and pesticides /
   Pyrethroid resistance / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Culicidae
OR Aedes aegypti (Culicidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15503012998
OA DOAJ Gold, Green Published
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15503014996
DT Article
TI Three new Paleocene dinoflagellate cysts from the North Sea and the
   Norwegian Sea.
AU Vieira, Manuel (Manuel.Vieira@Shell.com) 
   Mandi, Salih
   Casas-Gallego, Manuel
   Fenton, Jim
SO Review of Palaeobotany and Palynology
VL 258
PS 256-264
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Three dinoflagellate cysts species are formally described from Selandian
   and Danian sedimentary rocks of the North Sea and Norwegian Sea. The
   taxa are well known within the regional biostratigraphy community as
   important age markers, but have never been formally described.
   Thalassiphora lacunata sp. nov. differs from Thalassiphora delicata by
   possessing large, subcircular openings on the dorsal surface of the
   periphragm. For Spiniferites magnificus sp. nov., the morphology of the
   processes and the development of high sutural crests are the main
   diagnostic features to distinguish this species from other species of
   the genus Spiniferites. Operculodinium magnum sp. nov. differs from
   other Operculodinium species by its larger size and thicker wall, but
   also the distinctive numerous solid, fibrous processes. Spiniferites
   magnificus sp. nov. and O. magnum sp. nov. have a stratigraphic range
   restricted to the Danian. Thalassiphora lacunata sp. nov. has a short
   strati graphic range mainly restricted to the early Selandian. (C) 2018
   Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
C1 Vieira, Manuel; Shell UK Ltd, 1 Altens Farm Rd, Aberdeen, AB12 3FY,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM Manuel.Vieira@Shell.com

   Manuel/0000-0002-9802-9762

SN 0034-6667

   Atlantic; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Palaeogene

TI Harpactea gunselorum sp. n., a new spider species from northern Cyprus
   (Araneae: Dysderidae).
AU Gucel, Salih (sgucel@hotmail.com) 
   Fuller, Ozge Ozden
   Gocmen, Bayram
   Kunt, Kadir Bogac
SO Serket
VL 16
IS 2
PS 80-86
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the spider genus Harpactea Bristowe, 1939 is described
   from Cyprus. Detailed morphological description and photographs of both
   male and female specimens of the new species, Harpactea gunselorum sp.
   n., are provided. The taxonomic relationships of the new species are
   discussed.
C1 Gucel, Salih; Near East Univ, Environm Res Ctr, Nicosia, Cyprus, Cyprus.
EM sgucel@hotmail.com

PT J

DT Article
TI Contribution to the knowledge of the oribatid mite genus Leptotocepheus
   (Acari, Oribatida, Otocepheidae).
AU Ermilov, Sergey G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Minor, Maria A.
SO Systematic and Applied Acarology
VL 23
IS 11
PS 2269-2278
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The otocepheid oribatid mite genus Leptotocepheus Balogh, 1961 is
   recorded in the Australasian region for the first time. The taxonomic
   status of the genera Leptotocepheus Balogh, 1961 and Longocepheus Balogh
   & Mahunka,1966 is discussed, resulting in the recognition of
   Longocepheus as a subgenus (stat. nov.) of Leptotocepheus and the
   following recombinations: Leptotocepheus (Longocepheus) australis
   (Balogh & Mahunka, 1966) comb. nov., Leptotocepheus (Longocepheus)
   globosus (Grobler, 1995) comb. nov., Leptotocepheus (Longocepheus)
   longus (Balogh, 1961) comb. nov., Leptotocepheus (Longocepheus) youngai
   (Mahunka, 1984) comb. nov. A new species of Leptotocepheus
   (Longocepheus) is described from New Zealand, Leptotocepheus
   (Longocepheus) neozealandicus sp. nov., which differs from other species
   of the subgenus by the presence of short, slightly developed prodorsal
   costulae. Revised generic and subgeneric diagnoses, an identification
   key and distributions for the known taxa of Leptotocepheus are
   presented.
C1 Ermilov, Sergey G.; Tyumen State Univ, Tyumen, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru

PT J

PM 30324416
DT Article
TI Lepotrema Ozaki, 1932 (Lepocreadiidae: Digenea) from Indo-Pacific
   fishes, with the description of eight new species, characterised by
   morphometric and molecular features.
AU Bray, Rodney A. (rab@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Cutmore, Scott C.
   Cribb, Thomas H.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 693-741
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 2
U2 7
AB We review species of the genus Lepotrema Ozaki, 1932 from marine fishes
   in the Indo-West Pacific. Prior to the present study six species were
   recognised. Here we propose eight new species on the basis of combined
   morphological and molecular analysis: Lepotrema acanthochromidis n. sp.
   ex Acanthochromis polyacanthus from the Great Barrier Reef (GBR);
   Lepotrema hemitaurichthydis n. sp. ex Hemitaurichthys polylepis and H.
   thompsoni from Palau and French Polynesia; Lepotrema melichthydis n. sp.
   ex Melichthys vidua from Palau and the GBR; Lepotrema amansis n. sp. ex
   Amanses scopas from the GBR; Lepotrema cirripectis n. sp. ex Cirripectes
   filamentosus, C. chelomatus and C. stigmaticus from the GBR; Lepotrema
   justinei n. sp. ex Sufflamen fraenatum from New Caledonia; Lepotrema
   moretonense n. sp. ex Prionurus microlepidotus, P. maculatus and
   Selenotoca multifasciata from Moreton Bay; and Lepotrema
   amblyglyphidodonis n. sp. ex Amblyglyphidodon curacao and Amphipron
   akyndynos from the GBR. We also report new host records and provide
   novel molecular data for two known species: Lepotrema adlardi Bray,
   Cribb & Barker, 1993 and Lepotrema monile Bray & Cribb, 1998. Two new
   combinations are formed, Lepotrema cylindricum (Wang, 1989) n. comb.
   (for Preptetos cylindricus) and Lepotrema navodonis (Shen, 1986) n.
   comb. (for Lepocreadium navodoni). With the exception of a handful of
   ambiguous records, the evidence is compelling that the host-specificity
   of species in this genus is overwhelmingly oioxenous or stenoxenous.
   This renders the host distribution in three orders and ten families
   especially difficult to explain as many seemingly suitable hosts are not
   infected. Multi-loci molecular data (ITS2 rDNA, 28S rDNA and cox1 mtDNA)
   demonstrate that Lepotrema is a good generic concept, but limited
   variability in sequence data and differences in phylogenies produced for
   different gene regions make relationships within the genus difficult to
   define.
C1 Bray, Rodney A.; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Life Sci, Cromwell Rd, London,
   SW7 5BD, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM rab@nhm.ac.uk
RI Cutmore, Scott C/B-7385-2012
OI Cutmore, Scott C/0000-0002-5648-3684

PM 30350301
DT Article
TI Opistholobetines (Digenea: Opecoelidae) in Australian tetraodontiform
   fishes.
AU Martin, Storm B. (storm.martin@uqconnect.edu.au) 
   Ribu, Dalisay
   Cutmore, Scott C.
   Cribb, Thomas H.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 743-781
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Opistholebetine opecoelids are reported following examination of 1,041
   individual tetraodontiform fishes, comprising 60 species and seven
   families, collected in Australian waters between 1986 and 2018. Nine
   species consistent with Opistholebes Nicoll, 1915, Heterolebes Ozaki,
   1935 or Maculifer Nicoll, 1915 were recovered. However, phylogenetic
   analysis of sequence data, generated for some of these species,
   suggested that five genera, not three, are required to adequately
   accommodate these taxa. Thus, the concept and composition for each is
   revised, Pseudoheterolebes Yamaguti, 1959 nec Gupta, 1968 is resurrected
   and Parallelolebes n. g. is proposed. Of the nine species examined, five
   are new. Four new species are from fishes endemic to subtropical and
   temperate Australian waters for which no trematodes have previously been
   reported: Pa. australis n. sp. and Ps. corazonae n. sp. from the
   slender-spined porcupinefish Diodon nicthemerus Cuvier (Diodontidae) off
   Stanley, Tasmania; Pa. virilis n. sp. from the horse-shoe leatherjacket
   Meuschenia hippocrepis (Quoy & Gaimard) (Monacanthidae) off Stanley; and
   Ps. stellaglobulus n. sp. from the threebar pocupinefish Dicotylichthys
   punctulatus Kaup (Diodontidae) in Moreton Bay, south-east Queensland.
   The fifth new species is M. diodontis n. sp., collected from the spotted
   porcupinefish Diodon hystrix Linnaeus and the blackblotched
   porcupinefish D. liturosus Shaw, in tropical waters on the Great Barrier
   Reef. Species reported previously include the type-species of
   Opistholebes, O. amplicoelus Nicoll, 1915 from the rough golden puffer
   Lagocephalus lunaris (Bloch & Schneider) (Tetraodontidae) and the common
   toadfish Tetractenos hamiltoni (Richardson) (Tetraodontidae) in Moreton
   Bay, and three species reported for the first time from fishes in
   Australian waters: H. maculosus Ozaki, 1935, Pa. elongatus Ozaki, 1937
   n. comb. and Ps. diodontis (Cable, 1956) n. comb., each from both D.
   hystrix and D. liturosus on the Great Barrier Reef. Following the
   revisions, Opistholebes is recognised for two species, Heterolebes for
   five, Maculifer for eight, Pseudoheterolebes for five and Parallelolebes
   for three.
C1 Martin, Storm B.; Univ Queensland, Sch Biol Sci, Brisbane, Qld, 4072,
   Australia, Australia.
EM storm.martin@uqconnect.edu.au

   Storm/AAH-3150-2019

   Martin, Storm/0000-0001-8071-4609

   Bilqees & Nighat 1982, p. 772]. 
   Parallelolebes virilis (Digenea): [Sp nov, Australia, Tasmania (marine),
   Parasite of Meuschenia hippocrepis (Pisces), p. 771; Parasite].

PT J

PM 30284190
DT Article
TI Heterobucephalopsine and prosorhynchine trematodes (Digenea:
   Bucephalidae) from teleost fishes of Moreton Bay, Queensland, Australia,
   with the description of two new species.
AU Cutmore, Scott C. (scott.cutmore@uqconnect.edu.au) 
   Nolan, Matthew J.
   Cribb, Thomas H.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 783-806
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB Eight species of the trematode family Bucephalidae Poche, 1907 are
   reported from teleost fishes in Moreton Bay, Queensland, Australia.
   Heter-obucephalopsis yongi n. sp. is described from Gym-nothorax
   eurostus (Muraenidae); the new form is distinguished from its congeners
   in the possession of a tiny cirrus-sac relative to body length, the
   length of the caecum, the position of the mouth and pharynx, and the
   position of the testes and ovary. Two known species of Dollfustrema
   Eckmann, 1934, D. durum Nolan, Curran, Miller, Cutmore, Cantacessi &
   Cribb, 2015 and D. gibsoni Nolan & Cribb, 2010, are reported from
   Gymnothorax pseudothyrsoideus (Bleeker) (Muraenidae); although both
   species were described from Australian waters, this represents the first
   reports from Moreton Bay and G. pseudothyrsoideus. Four species of
   Prosorhynchus Odhner, 1905 are reported, including one new, P. brayi n.
   sp., which is described from Epinephelus coioides (Hamilton)
   (Serranidae); P. brayi n. sp. is distinguished from its congeners in the
   possession of vitelline follicles in a confluent arc distinctly
   posterior to a conical rhynchus, uterine coils that do not extend
   anterior to the vitelline arc, contiguous testes, a cirrus-sac that
   reaches anteriorly to at least the level of the posterior testis and a
   short excretory vesicle. Three known species of Prosorhynchus are
   reported from Australia, for the first time: P. luzonicus Velasquez,
   1959 and P. maternus Bray & Justine, 2006 from E. coioides and
   Prosorhynchus platycephali (Yamaguti, 1934) Srivastava, 1938 from
   Ambiserrula jugosa (McCulloch) and Inegocia japonica (Cuvier)
   (Platycephalidae). Skrjabiniella Issaitschikow, 1928 is re-recognised
   for new specimens of Skrjabiniella uniporus (Ozaki, 1924) n. comb.
   collected from Conger cinereus Ruppell (Congridae); three additional
   species of Prosorhynchus are considered members of this genus, two of
   which are synonymised with S. uniporus.
C1 Cutmore, Scott C.; Univ Queensland, Sch Biol Sci, Brisbane, Qld, 4072,
   Australia, Australia.

DT Article
TI Tetraphyllidean and onchoproteocephalidean cestodes of elasmobranchs
   from Moreton Bay, Australia: description of two new species and new
   records for seven described species.
AU Cutmore, Scott C. (scott.cutmore@uqconnect.edu.au) 
   Cribb, Thomas H.
   Bennett, Michael B.
   Beveridge, Ian
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 807-827
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 4
AB Parasitological examination of elasmobranchs of Moreton Bay, Queensland,
   Australia, resulted in the discovery of cestodes belonging to several
   armed genera of the Tetraphyllidea and Onchoproteocephalidea. Two new
   tetraphyllideans, Yorkeria moretonensis n. sp. and Yorkeria williamsi n.
   sp., are described from Chiloscyllium cf. punctatum (Hemiscylliidae).
   Yorkeria moretonensis n. sp. differs from its congeners in the
   possession of vitelline follicles that are discontinuous in the region
   of the ovary and in the length of its pedicels. Yorkeria williamsi n.
   sp. is most similar to Y. parva Southwell, 1927, but has larger, oval
   bothridia, longer pedicels and differences in the sizes of the scolex
   hooks. Yorkeria longstaffae Caira, Jensen & Rajan, 2007 is reported from
   Moreton Bay for the first time, and Spiniloculus mavensis Southwell,
   1925 is re-reported from the type-locality and likely type-host (Moreton
   Bay and Chiloscyllium cf. punctatum, respectively), over 90 years after
   its original description. Six known onchoproteocephalideans,
   Acanthobothrium cannoni Campbell & Beveridge, 2002, A. chisholmae
   Campbell & Beveridge, 2002, A. ocallaghani Campbell & Beveridge, 2002,
   A. margieae Fyler, 2011, Megalonchos shawae Caira, Reyda & Mega, 2007
   and M. sumansinghai Caira, Reyda & Mega, 2007, are reported from Moreton
   Bay for the first time, representing significant range extensions for
   all species.
C1 Cutmore, Scott C.; Univ Queensland, Sch Biol Sci, Brisbane, Qld, 4072,
   Australia, Australia.
EM scott.cutmore@uqconnect.edu.au
RI Bennett, Michael/A-7218-2012; Cutmore, Scott C/B-7385-2012

PM 30291541
DT Article
TI Four new species of dactylogyrids (Monogenea: Dactylogyridae) parasitic
   on gills of labrid and sparid fishes from Southeastern Pacific Ocean off
   Peru.
AU Cruces, Celso L.
   Chero, Jhon D.
   Luque, Jose L. (luqueufrrj@gmail.com) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 829-840
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB During a research on gill ectoparasites of Peruvian marine fishes, four
   dactylogyrid (Monogenea) species, parasitising two teleost species,
   Bodianus diplotaenia (Gill) (Labridae) and Calamus brachysomus
   (Lockington) (Sparidae), were found. Euryhaliotrema luisae n. sp. ex C.
   brachysomus is differentiated from other congeneric species by the
   morphology of the male copulatory organ, which comprises a coil of nine
   counterclockwise rings, and by the morphology of the anchors and bars.
   Euryhaliotrema magnopharyngis n. sp. ex C. brachysomus can be
   distinguished from all other congeners by having a well-developed
   pharynx occupying much of the anterior region and by the ventral bar,
   which is V-shaped, with well-elongated, thin arms. In addition, E.
   luisae n. sp. and E. magnopharyngis n. sp. can be differentiated from
   all other members of Euryhaliotrema Kritsky & Boeger, 2002 by the
   presence of a glandular oval plate lying on peduncle. Haliotrema
   diplotaenia n. sp. ex B. diplotaenia is characterised by the structure
   of the male copulatory organ, comprising a tapered-shaped cirrus tube
   with twisted acute tip and a filament-shaped accessory piece with medial
   and distal expansions, and by the morphology of the ventral bar
   (inverted W-shaped, with short lateral ends and two anterior conical
   protuberances). Haliotrema saezae n. sp. ex B. diplotaenia differs from
   all other members of Haliotrema Johnston & Tiegs, 1922 by having a
   tubular copulatory organ with curved distal tip and a filament-shaped
   accessory piece without lateral expansions, and by the morphology of
   anchors and bars. The present findings are added to the other six marine
   dactylogyrids previously reported from Peru.
C1 Luque, Jose L.; Univ Fed Rural Rio de Janeiro, Dept Parasitol Anim,
   Caixa Postal 74-540, Seropedica, RJ, BR-23851970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM luqueufrrj@gmail.com
RI Luque, Jose L/C-9767-2014
OI CHERO DE LA CRUZ, JHON DARLY/0000-0003-3633-1365; Luque,
   Jose/0000-0003-3515-1127

PM 30132206
DT Article
TI A new species of Kiluluma Skrjabin, 1916 (Nematoda: Strongyloidea) from
   the white rhinoceros, Ceratotherium simum (Burchell) from South Africa.
AU Beveridge, Ian (ibeve@unimelb.edu.au) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 841-847
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new species of Kiluluma Skrjabin, 1916, Kiluluma ornata n. sp., is
   described from the intestine of the white rhinoceros Ceratotherium simum
   (Burchell) from South Africa. The new species is virtually identical
   with a species described as Kiluluma sp., but not named due to a paucity
   of material then available. The new species most closely resembles K.
   solitaria Thapar, 1924 and K. ceratotherii Beveridge & Jabbar, 2013, in
   the possession of an undulating anterior margin of the buccal capsule
   but differs in the leaf crown elements which have bulbous, lip-like
   expansions, which are lacking in K. solitaria and K. ceratotherii.
C1 Beveridge, Ian; Univ Melbourne, Vet Clin Ctr, Werribee, Vic, 3030,
   Australia, Australia.
EM ibeve@unimelb.edu.au
SC Parasitology; Zoology
SN 0165-5752

   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Afrotropical region;
   Africa

   species] [South Africa /  / New nematode parasite species]. 
   Kiluluma ornata [Mammalian hosts / Ceratotherium simum / New parasite
   species] [South Africa /  / New species from mammalian host].

   Rhinocerotidae, Nematoda

DT Article
TI New Antarctic deep-sea weird leech (Hirudinida: Piscicolidae):
   morphological features and phylogenetic relationships.
AU Utevsky, Andriy (andriy.utevsky@karazin.ua) 
   Utevsky, Serge
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 849-861
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB A new fish leech Ambulobdella shandikovi n. g., n. sp. (Hirudinida:
   Piscicolidae), a parasite of Whitson's grenadier Macrourus whitsoni
   (Regan) (Macrouridae: Gadiformes) collected in the Ross Sea at depths
   from 1,221 to 1,433 m, is described and compared with related taxa based
   on morphological and molecular characters. Ambulobdella shandikovi n.
   sp. is characterised by prominent segmental tubercles on the venter and
   dorsal segmental tubercles, an uncommon appearance of its anterior
   sucker with ear-like edges and an inner membrane around the mouthpore,
   well-developed musculature and a unique combination of features of the
   reproductive and digestive systems. The presence of uncommon tubercles
   can be attributed, in part, to temporary associations of A. shandikovi
   n. sp. with its fish hosts and a need for well-developed sensory and
   locomotory organs. A certain locomotory function of ventrolateral
   tubercles of A. shandikovi n. sp. is hypothesised and discussed. Further
   deep-sea surveys are obviously needed to shed light on the behaviour and
   mode of locomotion of this species.
C1 Utevsky, Andriy; VN Karazin Kharkiv Natl Univ, 4 Maidan Svobody,
   Kharkiv, UA-61022, Ukraine, Ukraine.
EM andriy.utevsky@karazin.ua
OI Utevsky, Andrei/0000-0002-8336-1105

   diseases and disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Marine zones

PT J
AN ZOOR15503015689
PM 30232720
DT Article
TI Combined description (morphology with DNA barcode data) of a new quill
   mite Torotrogla paenae n. sp. (Acariformes: Syringophilidae)
   parasitising the Kalahari scrub-robin Cercotrichas paena (Smith)
   (Passeriformes: Muscicapidae) in Namibia.
AU Glowska, Eliza (glowska@amu.edu.pl) 
   Romanowska, Kamila
   Schmidt, Brian K.
   Dabert, Miroslawa
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 863-869
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A new quill mite species Torotrogla paenae n. sp. (Acariformes:
   Syringophilidae) para-sitising the Kalahari scrub-robin Cercotrichas
   paena (Smith) (Passeriformes: Muscicapidae) in Namibia is described
   based on the external morphology and DNA barcode data (the mitochondrial
   cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 sequences, cox1). Females of T. paenae n.
   sp. morphologically differ from the most similar species T. lusciniae
   Skoracki, 2004 by the total body length (780-830 vs 645-715 [mu]m in T.
   lusciniae) and the presence of hysteronotal shields (vs absence),
   apunctate propodonotal and pygidial shields (vs punctate), apunctate
   coxal fields (vs punctate), the fan-like setae p' and p'' of legs III-IV
   provided with c. 10 tines (vs 14-15) and the length of setae si (140-180
   vs 190-210 [mu]m) and se (160-185 vs 210-225 [mu]m). The male of T.
   paenae n. sp. morphologically differs from T. lusciniae by the lateral
   branch of peritremes composed of 4 chambers (vs 7-8 chambers) and
   lengths of setae ve (45 vs 70-75 [mu]m) and se (120 vs 165 [mu]m).

DT Article
TI Oswaldocruzia lanfrediae n. sp. (Strongylida: Molineidae), a parasite of
   Leptodactylus paraensis Heyer (Anura: Leptodactylidae) in Brazil.
AU Larrat, Yago Moises
   de Vasconcelos Melo, Francisco Tiago
   Furo Gomes, Tassia Fernanda
   Wilkens, Yuri
   dos Santos, Jeannie Nascimento (jeannie@ufpa.br) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 871-879
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Leptodactylus paraensis Heyer, is a Neotropical anuran species that
   inhabits Rainforest habitats in the eastern Amazon, but because it has
   only been recently separated from the Leptodactylus pentadactylus
   (Laurenti) species group, little is known about its helminth fauna. This
   study describes a new species of Oswaldocruzia Travassos, 1917 and
   records the first occurrence of this genus parasitising L. paraensis and
   the second species for the Caxiuana National Forest in the eastern
   Amazon, Brazil. Oswaldocruzia lanfrediae n. sp. is characterised by
   having an anterior extremity with a smooth cephalic vesicle divided into
   two portions, a claviform oesophagus, well-developed cuticular
   longitudinal ridges and lateral alae. Females have a well-developed
   ovojector, with didelphic and amphidelphic uteri. Males show complex
   robust spicules divided into a slightly curved shoe, a bifurcated fork
   and a blade terminating in 2-3 processes. The new species differs from
   its congeners especially regarding the lateral alae and the morphology
   of the spicules, in addition to morphometric characters such as body
   size, oesophagus length, deirid position, nerve-ring position and
   relative position of the vulva in females.
C1 dos Santos, Jeannie Nascimento; Fed Univ Para, Inst Biol Sci, Av Augusto
   Correa 01, Belem, Para, BR-66075110 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM jeannie@ufpa.br
RI NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS, JEANNIE/F-7130-2012
OI NASCIMENTO DOS SANTOS, JEANNIE/0000-0002-6612-6410

   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America

   New parasite species] [ / Oswaldocruzia / New record] [Brazil /  / ] [ /
    / New nematode parasite species].

PM 30151613
DT Article
TI Two new species of Sagum Wilson, 1913 (Copepoda: Siphonostomatoida:
   Lernanthropidae) parasitic on reef fishes off the Ryukyu Islands.
AU Uyeno, Daisuke (duyeno@sci.kagoshima-u.ac.jp) 
   Naruse, Tohru
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 893-904
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Two new species of parasitic copepods, Sagum gurukun n. sp. and S.
   bitaro n. sp. (Siphonostomatoida: Lernanthropidae), are described based
   on specimens collected from the gill filaments of the double-lined
   fusilier Pterocaesio digramma (Bleeker) (Actinopterygii: Perciformes:
   Caesionidae) and the five-lined snapper Lutjanus quinquelineatus (Bloch)
   (Actinopterygii: Perciformes: Lutjanidae), respectively, caught off
   Iriomote-jima Island, the Ryukyu Islands, East China Sea, Japan. The
   findings bring the number of species of Sagum to 14. The two new species
   are similar in the morphology of the head and the legs 3 and 4 to the
   three congeners, S. folium Ho, Liu & Liu, 2011, S. paracaesionis Izawa,
   2014 and S. vietnamiensis Kazachenko, Kovaleva, Nguyen & Ngo, 2017.
   Sagum gurukun n. sp. is differentiated from the three congeners by the
   proportions of the caudal rami, the absence of leg 5, and the shape of
   the legs 1 and 2. Sagum bitaro n. sp. differs from the three congeners
   and S. gurukun n. sp. by the presence of the conical leg 5 armed with an
   apical seta. A key to the species of the genus Sagum, based on the
   available information on female morphology in previous publications and
   the present study, is provided. To date, a total of 19 species of
   lernanthropid copepods considered valid are known in Japanese waters.

   Kagoshima, 8900065, Japan, Japan.
EM duyeno@sci.kagoshima-u.ac.jp

DT Article
TI Octopicola huanghaiensis n. sp. (Copepoda: Cyclopoida: Octopicolidae), a
   new parasitic copepod of the octopuses Amphioctopus fangsiao (d'Orbigny)
   and Octopus minor (Sasaki) (Octopoda: Octopodidae) in the Yellow Sea.
AU Du, Xin
   Dong, Chao
   Sun, Shi-Chun (sunsc@ouc.edu.cn) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 95
IS 8-9
PS 905-912
PD Nov 2018
PY 2018
LA English
U1 0
U2 9
AB A new species of parasitic copepod, Octopicola huanghaiensis n. sp.,
   collected from the octopuses Amphioctopus fangsiao (d'Orbigny) and
   Octopus minor (Sasaki) (Octopoda: Octopodidae) in the Yellow Sea (off
   Qingdao, Shandong Province, China), is described. The new species is
   most similar to O. superba Humes, 1957, but can be distinguished from
   the latter by: (i) the third antennal segment having a different
   ornamentation; (ii) the fourth antennal segment of females much shorter
   than that in O. superba (49 vs 94 [mu]m); (iii) males much smaller than
   females (mean body length 1.3 vs 2.0 mm, respectively) (vs similar male
   and female body size in O. superba, 1.9 mmand 1.8 mm respectively); and
   (iv) the presence of a spike at the posterior tip of each labrum flap.
   Octopicola huanghaiensis n. sp. is the first species of Octopicola
   Humes, 1957 reported from A. fangsiao and O. minor and is the only
   species of the family Octopicolidae Humes & Boxshall, 1996 known in
   North Pacific waters.

   Qingdao, Shandong, 266003, China, China.
